content:
COMPUTER SYSTEMS ENGINEERING 
COMPUTER VISION – 2ND YEAR 
Academic Year 2024/2025 
 
Polytechnic Institute of Cávado and Ave 
Higher School of Technology 
Page 1/ 3 
 
 
 
Practical Work 
 
 
 
 
Summary 
This work aims to give students the opportunity to apply some of the image processing and analysis concepts 
covered in class. Students must develop a program in C or C++, which operates on the video made available for 
this practical work, in order to obtain the desired set of information (see below). This work will culminate in the 
delivery of the developed source code , in addition to the mandatory oral defense of the work carried out. 
 
 
Carrying out practical work 
The file “ VC-TP.zip ” presents the respective description of the work and objectives, also containing: 
• 
Videos “video1.mp4” and “video2.mp4”; 
• 
Source code with an example of reading/capturing and displaying video using the OpenCV library . 
The work must be developed in groups, and groups must be made up of 4 elements . 
Students are expected to use the knowledge acquired throughout the Computer Vision classes and develop the 
functionalities necessary to achieve the objectives. 
Note that all code must be written in C or C++ language, and the student may use (in addition to the OpenCV 
functions identified in the file “CodigoExemplo.cpp”, or similar functions, depending on the version of OpenCV ) up 
to 3 more functions or instances of classes from the OpenCV library . For example, the following line of code 
would hit this limit, because it uses cv::rectangle(), cv::Point(), and cv::Scalar(): 
cv::rectangle(frame, cv::Point(10, 2), cv::Point(100,20), cv::Scalar(255,255,255), -1); 
Not permitted: external image processing libraries not covered in classes; code made available in repositories 
(such as GitHub); as well as any other code whose authorship is not that of the elements that make up the group. 
The work must also be presented/defended by all group members in an oral presentation/defense, with 
questions about the work being asked to the various group members. No report or PowerPoint presentation 
completion is required. The presentation/defense should focus on the strategy followed and its implementation 
(source code), the difficulties experienced and the resolution found for them. Students are expected to master all 
the source code used by the group to solve the practical work. 
 
 
Objective 
This work aims to develop a program in C language, or C++, that allows the automatic quantification of money in 
videos. In this sense, the program must read a given file indicated by the user (in *.mp4 format), identify all the 
coins visible throughout the video, and present the respective sum. Furthermore, the following set of information 
should be made available during and/or after video processing (about this): 
• 
Total number of coins observed throughout the video; 
• 
Number of coins per type (1, 2, 5, 10, 20 or 50 cents, and 1 or 2 euros); 
• 
Area and perimeter (in pixels) of all coins observed throughout the video;
[['COMPUTER SYSTEMS ENGINEERING', None], ['COMPUTER VISION – 2ND YEAR', 'Academic Year 2024/2025']]
ESCOLA SUPERIOR DE TECNOLOGIA IPCA

content:
COMPUTER SYSTEMS ENGINEERING 
COMPUTER VISION – 2ND YEAR 
Academic Year 2024/2025 
 
Polytechnic Institute of Cávado and Ave 
Higher School of Technology 
Page 2/ 3 
 
• 
Drawing, on the image to be displayed on video, of the location (bounding box) and center of gravity of 
each coin, as well as an indication of its respective type. 
 
Please also note that: 
• 
The videos all have a resolution of 1280x720; 
• 
Videos have a frame rate of 30 fps . 
 
 
System Specification 
The computer vision system must include: 
• 
Implementation of segmentation techniques (by hue and/or brightness); 
• 
Implementation of image enhancement techniques (eg, noise removal); 
• 
Implementation of image analysis techniques that allow determining: 
o 
Area; 
o 
Bounding box; 
o 
Circularity of segmented objects; 
o 
Center of mass (centroid); among other information that the group understands as relevant. 
• 
Algorithms that allow different currencies to be distinguished. 
 
 
Assessment 
The following factors will be taken as evaluation criteria: 
• 
Program quality: 
o 
development of the functionalities described in the work statement; 
o 
level of optimization of implemented functions; 
o 
correct functioning of the program; 
o 
added value 1. 
• 
Quality of the code and respective comments, as well as the oral presentation: 
o 
correct and complete description of the program structure; 
o 
description of the techniques applied in the development of functionalities. 
• 
Respect for the rules for submitting work. 
• 
Level of knowledge that the student has about the work developed. 
The collective nature of carrying out group work does not affect the fact that the assessment is individual for each 
member of the group. 
Each member of the group must demonstrate knowledge of all submitted code. 
 
 
 
 
1Added value is understood as the way in which the work stands out (positively) from the rest.

content:
COMPUTER SYSTEMS ENGINEERING 
COMPUTER VISION – 2ND YEAR 
Academic Year 2024/2025 
 
Polytechnic Institute of Cávado and Ave 
Higher School of Technology 
Page 3/ 3 
 
 
IMPORTANT NOTES: 
• 
The defense of the work is mandatory. Failure to do so will result in the assignment of 0 (zero) points to the 
practical component. 
• 
For the defense, on the scheduled day, the group must bring at least one PC with editable and compilable 
code. However, it is recommended that they bring more than one computer to prevent possible problems. 
• 
The source code for the presentation/defense must be the same as that submitted for evaluation, but all 
comments must be removed beforehand . 
 
Deadlines 
Carrying out the work presupposes the delivery of files with the source code , in digital format. Do not upload the 
project folder , but only the source code files ( .c / .h or .cpp / .hpp ) . 
The work must be sent to the professor via the submission link available on the Moodle page of this UC, by the 
defined date and time (also available on the UC's Moodle page). 
 
The submission of practical work must comply with the following requirements: 
• 
The source code files should be placed in a zip file named “ VC-GY-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx.zip ”, where: 
o 
 xxxx must be filled in with the student number of each member of the group ); 
o 
GY should be filled in with G1 for group 1, G2 for group 2, etc. 
• 
Only 1 (one) member of each group should submit the work. 
• 
The name of the zip file should only include the numbers of the students who actually completed the work 
and who will therefore be subject to evaluation. 
The deadline for submissions is May 19th at 11:00 pm . Works submitted after this date will not be considered 
. 
 
 
Ethical conduct 
The lack of transparency in assessments, whether in person or not, is naturally illegal and immoral. All sources 
used to support work must be clearly referenced. Any plagiarism, copying or inappropriate academic conduct will 
be penalized with the cancellation of the work. If there are clearly similar works (where, for example, only the 
names of variables in another code have been changed) between groups, all similar works will be cancelled .
[['COMPUTER SYSTEMS ENGINEERING', None], ['COMPUTER VISION – 2ND YEAR', 'Academic Year 2024/2025']]

content:
Simple Plan for a 3D Viewer Application with Head Tracking
Milestone 1: Basic 3D Viewer Application (Days 1-5)
Goal: Create a simple application to view 3D models on your computer.
Steps:
1. Set up the basic app structure using a tool called Electron.js.
2. Create a simple 3D scene using Babylon.js with a camera (to look around) and lighting.
3. Add a way to load 3D models (like .glb, .gltf, .obj files).
4. Allow basic controls to rotate and zoom the model.
5. Ensure the model looks good with realistic materials and smooth edges.
6. Package the app for easy use.
Outcome:
A working app that can display 3D models with basic manual controls.
Diagram:
Electron.js App
Babylon.js Scene
Model Loading + Controls
Milestone 2: Head Tracking Implementation (Days 6-10)
Goal: Make the app track head movements to adjust the view.
Steps:
1. Use a tool called OpenCV to detect your face and head position.
2. Write a small program to track how your head moves.
3. Send the tracking data to the app using a connection.
4. Test the head tracking to ensure it works well.
5. Smooth out any jitters to make it look natural.
6. Create a basic visual to show the tracking data.
1

Milestone 3: Integration and Refinement (Days 11-15)
Goal: Combine the 3D viewer and head tracking for a complete app.
Steps:
1. Link the head tracking data to the 3D scene.
2. Adjust the 3D view based on head movements.
3. Fine-tune settings to make it smooth and accurate.
4. Add a button to turn head tracking on or off.
5. Improve the interface to hide controls when not needed.
6. Package everything into one complete app.
Outcome:
A fully functional app that adjusts the 3D view based on your head movements.

metadata.description: a document with the title title and title title

content: Introduction

The report is titled "Finding Kth Shortest Path Length" and is authored by Waqas Khan, Luqman Ansari, and Huzaifa Khalid. It was written during the Spring 2023 semester for the Parallel and Distributed Computing course at FAST NUCES.
Abstract

This study investigates the parallelization of graph shortest path algorithms using a combination of MPI and OpenMP in a distributed computing environment. The project aims to evaluate the effectiveness of parallelization in reducing execution time and improving performance across different datasets and processing configurations. Through experimentation and analysis, the study explores the impact of increasing the number of processes on execution time, speedup, and the scalability of parallel implementations. The findings reveal varying degrees of speedup achieved across datasets, with significant improvements observed in some cases but diminishing returns in others. Challenges such as load imbalance, synchronization overhead, and limited parallelism are identified as factors influencing parallel efficiency, particularly in operations involving priority queues. Despite these challenges, the study demonstrates the potential of parallelization to optimize computation times and handle larger workloads efficiently. The insights gained from this project contribute to the understanding of parallel algorithm design and provide valuable guidance for optimizing performance in distributed computing environments.
Distribution of the Task using MPI
Initialization and Setup
MPI is initialized, establishing communication channels among processes.Each process is assigned a unique identifier within the MPI communicator.
Random Edge Selection
The program selects a subset of edges randomly from the graph. These randomly selected edges are stored in the randomEdges array.
Division of Work

The randomEdges array is divided among processes to distribute the workload evenly.The total number of edges in randomEdges is divided by the number of processes to determine the portion of edges each process will handle.
Balanced Distribution
If the number of edges in randomEdges is not evenly divisible by the number of processes, the remainder is distributed among the first few processes to ensure all edges are processed.
Local Computation
Each process independently computes the k shortest paths for the subset of edges it has been assigned.
The findKShortest function is invoked for each edge in the local subset to compute the k shortest paths.
Insights
Increasing Execution Time with Increasing Processes

As the number of processes increases from 1 to 5, the execution time generally decreases across all datasets.This reduction in execution time indicates that parallelizing the computation using multiple processes leads to improved performance, as the workload is distributed among more processing units.
Varying Speedup Across Datasets

The degree of speedup achieved by increasing the number of processes varies depending on the dataset.For example, in the case of "email-Enron.txt" and "email-EuAll.txt", the speedup from 1 to 5 processes is significant, with a notable reduction in execution time.

However, for datasets like "class-who.csv", "doctorwho.csv", and "new-who.csv", the speedup is less pronounced, indicating that the parallelization benefits may be limited due to factors such as dataset size, computation complexity, or communication overhead.
Effectiveness of Parallelization
The data suggests that parallelization is effective in reducing execution time, particularly for larger datasets or computationally intensive tasks.
The observed reduction in execution time demonstrates the scalability of the parallel implementation, as it is able to efficiently utilize multiple processing units to handle larger workloads.
Challenges in Parallelizing Graph K-Shortest Path Algorithm in Distributed Environments
Sequential Operations

Priority queues typically rely on sequential operations, such as insertion, deletion, and traversal, to maintain their order. In the context of finding shortest paths, these operations are essential for exploring neighboring nodes in order of their distances from the source node.
Data Dependency

The order in which elements are inserted or removed from the priority queue directly impacts the outcome of the shortest path algorithm. As a result, concurrent access or modification of the priority queue by multiple processes can lead to data races, inconsistencies, or incorrect results.
Synchronization Overhead

To parallelize the code using a distributed environment like MPI, processes would need to coordinate their access to the priority queue to avoid data corruption or race conditions. This necessitates synchronization mechanisms, such as locks or barriers, which introduce overhead and may limit scalability.
Load Imbalance

Distributing the workload among multiple processes while maintaining the integrity of the priority queue can be challenging. Load imbalance may occur if certain processes have more work to do (e.g., processing nodes with higher degrees) or encounter longer execution times due to contention for shared resources.
Limited Parallelism

The sequential nature of priority queue operations inherently limits the degree of parallelism that can be achieved. While some parallelization may be possible, especially in certain phases of the algorithm, the overall parallel efficiency may be constrained by the sequential bottleneck imposed by the priority queue.
Distribution with Parallelism of the    Task using MPI and OpenMP
Insights
Impact of Increasing Processes

For some datasets like "email-Enron.txt" and "email-EuAll.txt," the execution time initially decreases as the number of processes increases from 1 to 2. However, further increasing the number of processes to 3 or 4 results in increased execution times.
Conversely, for datasets like "class-who.csv," "doctorwho.csv," and "new-who.csv," the execution time consistently increases as the number of processes increases.
Optimal Parallelization Point

The optimal number of processes varies depending on the dataset. In some cases, the execution time is minimized with a small number of processes (e.g., 1 or 2), while in others, a higher number of processes may lead to better performance.
Impact of Workload and Parallelization Strategy
The effectiveness of parallelization depends on factors such as the size and complexity of the dataset, as well as the efficiency of the parallelization strategy (combining MPI and OpenMP).

For datasets with smaller or less complex graphs, parallelization may not provide significant benefits, and increasing the number of processes beyond a certain point may introduce overhead and degrade performance.
Conclusion

In conclusion, parallelizing the computation using multiple processes generally leads to improved performance, as evidenced by the reduction in execution time across all datasets as the number of processes increases. However, the degree of speedup varies depending on the dataset, with some datasets exhibiting significant reductions in execution time, while others show less pronounced improvements. The observed effectiveness of parallelization underscores the scalability of the parallel implementation, although challenges such as load imbalance, synchronization overhead, and limited parallelism, particularly in operations involving priority queues, may constrain overall parallel efficiency. Despite these challenges, the data demonstrates the potential of parallelization to efficiently handle larger workloads and optimize computation times, particularly for datasets with complex graphs or computationally intensive tasks.
References
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/1st-to-kth-shortest-path-lengths-from-node-1-to-n-in-given-graph/
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/parallel-dijkstras-algorithm-sssp-in-parallel/
https://repository.stcloudstate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1044&context=csit_etds

content: Software Requirements and Design Document
For
Ms. Sidra Khalid,
Lecturer, FAST NUCES.
BeneCare: Empowering Welfare      Management
Prepared by
Cortex Technologies Pvt Ltd.
December 3rd,2023
Introduction
Purpose

The purpose of this Software Requirements Specification (SRS) document is to outline the functional and non-functional requirements for the development of "BeneCARE: Empowering Welfare Management" software. This comprehensive software aims to address challenges in managing social welfare programs at a city-wide level. The project's primary objectives are to automate and streamline processes related to beneficiary registration, eligibility assessment, application workflow, case management, benefit distribution, reporting, and communication. By doing so, the project intends to enhance the efficiency, transparency, and fairness of welfare program management.
1.2 Product Scope
The scope of “BeneCARE: Empowering Welfare Management" includes a range of activities and functionalities aimed at well and fairly managing social welfare programs on a city-wide level.
Title
BeneCARE: Empowering Welfare Management.
Objectives
Efficiency Enhancement
Streamline and automate welfare management processes to reduce administrative overhead, eliminate manual paperwork, and optimize resource utilization.
Transparency Improvement
Enhance transparency in the management of social welfare programs, providing stakeholders with clear visibility into processes, benefit distribution, and program performance.
Equitable Support
Establish fair and consistent benefit distribution processes based on predefined eligibility criteria, ensuring equitable support for beneficiaries.
Data Accuracy and Security
Implement secure user authentication and access control mechanisms to ensure the accuracy and integrity of data within the system, preventing unauthorized access.
Public Access and Awareness
Create a public portal to educate potential beneficiaries about available programs, eligibility criteria, and the application process, promoting public awareness and accessibility.
Continuous Improvement Mechanisms
Implement feedback and evaluation mechanisms to continuously improve the system's efficiency, effectiveness, and responsiveness to community needs.
Automated Eligibility Assessment
Develop and deploy automated eligibility assessment processes to efficiently determine whether an applicant qualifies for welfare assistance, reducing processing time.
Comprehensive Case Management
Provide caseworkers with comprehensive tools to manage beneficiary cases efficiently, including tracking applications, conducting interviews, and recording case notes.
Transparent Benefit Distribution
Automate the calculation and distribution of benefits, ensuring transparency in allocation and providing beneficiaries with clear records of the assistance received (optional).
Problem Statement

Traditional welfare programs often suffer from inefficiencies due to manual paperwork, redundant processes, and lack of proper data management; however, the undertaken project streamlines the management of welfare programs by automating processes, reducing administrative overhead, and improving data accuracy.

In Addition to that, without proper systems in place, there can be inconsistencies in how benefits are distributed, leading to inequality and dissatisfaction among beneficiaries. This project will hopefully establish transparent and fair benefit distribution processes based on predefined eligibility criteria, ensuring equitable support for those in need.

Lastly, a lack of efficient welfare systems can hinder communities' ability to respond to and recover from crises and emergencies. This project helps communities become more resilient by providing timely support, resources, and assistance during challenging times.
Overall Description
Product Perspective

The BeneCARE: Empowering Welfare Management system is a standalone product designed to revolutionize the management of social welfare programs on a city-wide level. It is not a follow-on member of an existing product family but serves as an innovative solution to address the inefficiencies of traditional welfare programs. The system is not a replacement for existing systems but aims to enhance and modernize the entire process of welfare management.
Context

BeneCARE operates within the context of city-wide social welfare programs, providing a comprehensive platform to streamline beneficiary registration, eligibility assessment, application processing, case management, benefit distribution, reporting, and communication.
Origin

The origin of BeneCARE is rooted in the need for more efficient, transparent, and equitable welfare program management. It is initiated to overcome challenges associated with manual paperwork, redundant processes, and a lack of proper data management in traditional welfare systems.
Product Functions
User Authentication and Access Control
Implement secure user authentication to ensure that only authorized personnel can access and modify the system's data.
Define user roles and access levels, such as administrators, caseworkers, and beneficiaries, with appropriate permissions.
Beneficiary Registration:
Create a system for registering beneficiaries by collecting their personal information, contact details, family composition, and demographic data.
Verify and validate beneficiary information to prevent fraudulent claims.
Eligibility Assessment:
Develop eligibility criteria for various welfare programs and assistance types, such as income thresholds, family size, and specific needs.
Automate the eligibility assessment process to determine whether an applicant qualifies for assistance.
Application Workflow:
Create a structured workflow for processing applications, including application submission, verification, approval, and benefit distribution.
Enable notifications and alerts to keep applicants informed about the status of their applications.
Case Management:
Provide caseworkers with tools to manage beneficiary cases efficiently, including tracking applications, conducting interviews, and recording case notes.
Benefit Distribution:
Automate the calculation and distribution of benefits, whether in the form of financial assistance, food vouchers, or other resources.
Ensure transparency in benefit allocation and provide beneficiaries with clear records of the assistance received. (Optional)
Reporting and Analytics:
Generate reports and dashboards to monitor program performance, track expenditures, and identify trends in beneficiary data.
Use data analytics to detect anomalies or potentially fraudulent activities. (Optional)
Communication and Notifications:
Implement a communication module to send notifications, reminders, and announcements to beneficiaries and caseworkers through email, SMS, or a mobile app.
Public Access Portal:
Create a public portal where potential beneficiaries can learn about available programs, eligibility criteria, and the application process.
Continuous Improvement:
Implement mechanisms for feedback and evaluation to continuously improve the system's efficiency and effectiveness.
List of Use Cases
Benefactor
Add Beneficiary Program.

Extended Use Cases
Use Case Diagram
Other Nonfunctional Requirements
Performance Requirements

The performance requirements for the BeneCARE: Empowering Welfare Management system are integral to its efficacy in delivering timely and efficient services. The system is mandated to exhibit a response time of less than 3 seconds for user interactions, ensuring prompt and seamless engagement. This is crucial for user satisfaction, particularly during application submissions, eligibility assessments, and benefit distribution processes. Additionally, the system must support a minimum of 500 concurrent users without a substantial decline in performance. This scalability requirement is essential to accommodate varying levels of user activity, especially during peak periods, preventing any adverse impact on system responsiveness. Furthermore, the system is expected to achieve a minimum throughput of 1000 transactions per minute during peak usage, emphasizing the importance of robust data processing capabilities. This throughput requirement is fundamental to the expeditious processing of welfare applications and the efficient allocation of benefits, contributing significantly to the overall performance and effectiveness of the welfare management system.
Safety Requirements

The safety requirements for the BeneCARE: Empowering Welfare Management system focus on ensuring the protection of data, preventing unauthorized access, and mitigating potential risks. Safety measures are implemented to avoid any loss, damage, or harm resulting from the use of the product.
The system must have mechanisms in place to ensure the integrity of the data, preventing any corruption or unauthorized modifications.
Regular automated backups of system data must be performed to facilitate quick recovery in the event of data loss or system failures.
Robust user authentication mechanisms must be implemented to prevent unauthorized access to sensitive information and functionalities.
The system should maintain detailed audit trails for user activities to enable tracking and investigation in case of any discrepancies or security incidents.
the system involves physical components or infrastructure, ensure that appropriate physical security measures are in place to protect against theft, damage, or unauthorized access.
Ensure that the system complies with relevant safety regulations and standards, taking into account any legal or regulatory requirements related to welfare management software.
Security Requirements
The security requirements for BeneCARE address the protection of sensitive information, user identity authentication, and compliance with privacy regulations.
All communication channels and stored data must be encrypted to protect against unauthorized access or data breaches.
Multi-factor authentication (MFA) should be implemented to enhance user identity verification and access control.
Define access control policies to restrict users' access to specific functionalities and data based on their roles and responsibilities.
Ensure compliance with data protection and privacy regulations applicable to welfare management systems, safeguarding the confidentiality and privacy of beneficiary information.
Develop and implement an incident response plan outlining the steps to be taken in case of security incidents, including reporting procedures and communication protocols.
Obtain and maintain relevant security certifications to demonstrate the system's adherence to industry-recognized security standards and best practices.
Conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments to identify and address potential security threats and weaknesses.
Provide training to users, especially administrators and case workers, on security best practices and the importance of safeguarding sensitive information.
Certification required:
SOC 2 (Service Organization Control 2)
PCI DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard)
Software Quality Attributes
Adaptability
Specification: The system should be adaptable to changes in welfare program regulations and evolving user requirements, aiming to accommodate at least two major updates per year.
Verification: Track the frequency and success of updates over a year, ensuring the system remains adaptable to changing external factors.
Availability
Specification: Aim for 99.9% availability, allowing for scheduled maintenance. Users should be notified in advance of any planned downtime.
Verification: Monitor system uptime, ensuring it meets the specified availability target. Collect user feedback on the notification process during maintenance.
Correctness
Specification: Maintain a low bug density, targeting fewer than 1 critical bug per 1000 lines of code to ensure high software correctness.
Verification: Regularly conduct code reviews and analyze bug reports, aiming to keep the bug density within the specified limit.
Flexibility
Specification: Design the system to be flexible and extensible, allowing for the integration of new welfare programs or changes in eligibility criteria without significant code modifications.
Verification: Assess the ease with which the system incorporates new welfare programs or eligibility criteria through controlled experiments or simulations.
Interoperability
Specification: The system should seamlessly integrate with external databases for beneficiary verification and validation.
Verification: Confirm successful integration with external databases through predefined test cases, ensuring smooth interoperability.
Maintainability
Specification: Adhere to coding standards, and aim for a code complexity rating of less than 12, as measured by cyclomatic complexity, to ensure maintainability.
Verification: Regularly use code analysis tools to check adherence to coding standards and measure code complexity.
Portability
Specification: The software should be portable across different operating systems, with a focus on Windows and at least one other major OS (e.g., Linux).
Verification: Test the system on multiple operating systems, ensuring consistent performance and functionality.
Reliability
Specification: Maintain a mean time between failures (MTBF) of at least 25 days, ensuring reliable system operation.
Verification: Track system failures over time and calculate MTBF, ensuring it meets the specified reliability target.
Reusability
Specification: Design code modules to be reusable across different welfare programs or features, aiming for a module reuse rate of at least 75%.
Verification: Analyze codebase metrics to assess the extent of module reuse across different functionalities.
Robustness
Specification: The system should be robust, gracefully handling unexpected inputs or spikes in user activity to prevent crashes or data corruption.
Verification: Conduct stress testing and validate how well the system handles unexpected inputs, monitoring error rates during testing.
Testability
Specification: Aim for a test coverage of at least 85%, ensuring comprehensive testing of the system's functionalities.
Verification: Regularly assess test coverage using automated testing tools and conduct manual testing to validate coverage.
Usability:
Specification: Achieve a System Usability Scale (SUS) score of 80 or higher, emphasizing an intuitive and user-friendly experience.
Verification: Conduct usability testing with representative users and measure the SUS score to ensure the system meets usability expectations
Business Rules
1.  User Authentication
Rule: Only registered users with valid credentials, such as administrators, caseworkers, and authorized personnel, can access and modify the system's data.
Implication: Implementation of a secure user authentication mechanism to enforce access control.
2. User Roles and Permissions
Rule: User roles (administrators, caseworkers, beneficiaries) will have specific access levels and permissions tailored to their responsibilities.
Implication: Define and implement role-based access control to ensure appropriate access to functionalities for each user role.
3. Beneficiary Registration Verification
Rule: Beneficiary information provided during registration must be verified and validated to prevent fraudulent claims.
Implication: Implementation of validation processes and data verification checks during the beneficiary registration phase.
4. Eligibility Criteria Adherence
Rule: Eligibility criteria, such as income thresholds, family size, and specific needs, must be strictly adhered to in determining an applicant's qualification for assistance.
Implication: Automation of the eligibility assessment process to ensure accurate and consistent application of criteria.
5. Application Workflow Management
Rule: Applications must follow a structured workflow, including submission, verification, approval, and benefit distribution phases.
Implication: Design and implementation of a workflow system to manage the application lifecycle efficiently.
6. Case Management Consistency
Rule: Caseworkers are responsible for maintaining consistency in managing beneficiary cases, including tracking applications, conducting interviews, and recording case notes.
Implication: Providing caseworkers with tools for efficient case management and documentation.
7.Benefit Distribution Transparency
Rule: Benefit distribution processes must be transparent, and beneficiaries should receive clear records of the assistance they have received.
Implication: Implementation of automated benefit calculation and distribution mechanisms with transparent reporting.
8. Communication Module Usage
Rule: The communication module should be used to send notifications, reminders, and announcements to beneficiaries and caseworkers through email, SMS, or a mobile app.
Implication: Integration of a communication module for efficient and timely communication.
9. Public Portal Information Accuracy
Rule: Information on the public portal about available programs, eligibility criteria, and the application process must be accurate and up-to-date.
Implication: Regular updates and synchronization of information between the internal system and the public portal.
10. Continuous Improvement Feedback Mechanism
Rule: Mechanisms for feedback and evaluation must be actively used to continuously improve the system's efficiency and effectiveness.
Implication: Integration of feedback forms, surveys, and analytics to gather input for system enhancements.
Operating Environment
Windows Version
The software is designed to operate on Microsoft Windows platforms.
Example: Windows 10, Windows Server 2019.
Hardware Platform
Processor: The software should be compatible with the standard processors used in Windows-based systems.
Example: Intel Core series, AMD Ryzen series.
Memory (RAM): The software should run smoothly with a standard amount of system memory.
Example: 8 GB RAM or higher.
Storage: The software will require disk space for installation and data storage.
Example: 20 GB of free disk space.
Network Connectivity: Internet connectivity is required for certain features, such as sending notifications or accessing online resources.
Software Components
Database Management System (DBMS): It uses a database, it requires a specific DBMS.
Example: Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL.
Programming Language Runtimes: The program needs to be run on JAVA compatibles.
Example: Eclipse.

Define the software components for which a user interface is needed. Details of the user interface design should be documented in a separate user interface specification.>

[['Use Case Section', 'Comment'], ['Use Case Name', 'Register Beneficiary'], ['Scope', 'BeneCare'], ['Level', 'User-goal'], ['Primary Actor', 'CaaseWorker'], ['Stockholders & Interest', 'Caseworker: wants to register new beneficiaries quickly and accurately using the system’s functions.
Administrator: wants to maintain a reliable and up-to-date database of beneficiaries and their information.
Beneficiary: wants to provide their information to the city and receive welfare assistance in a timely and transparent manner.
'], ['Pre-conditions', 'The caseworker has logged in to the system and has permission to register beneficiaries.
The beneficiary has agreed to provide their information to the city and has consented to the verification and validation process.
'], ['Post-Condition', 'A new beneficiary record is created in the database with a unique identifier and the beneficiary’s information.'], ['Main Success Scenario', 'The caseworker selects the register beneficiary option from the system’s interface.
The system displays a registration form with fields for personal information, contact details, family composition, and demographic data.
The caseworker fills in the registration form with the information provided by the beneficiary or obtained from other sources.
The system validates the input data and checks for any errors or missing information.
The caseworker submits the registration form to the system.
The system creates a new beneficiary record in the database and assigns a unique identifier to it.
The system displays a confirmation message and shows the beneficiary’s details to the caseworker.
'], ['Extensions/Alternatives', '4a. The input data is invalid or incomplete: 
The system displays an error message and highlights the fields that need to be corrected or filled in. 
2. The caseworker can edit the input data and resubmit the registration form.
Repeat.
']]

[['Use Case Section', 'Comment'], ['Use Case Name', 'Process Application'], ['Scope', 'BeneCARE: Empowering Welfare Management'], ['Level', 'User-goal'], ['Primary Actor', 'CaseWorker'], ['Stockholders & Interest', 'Caseworker: Wants to efficiently process welfare program applications and ensure that eligible beneficiaries receive benefits.
Beneficiaries: Expect timely processing and approval of their applications.
Administrator: Requires accurate and complete processing of applications for authorization.
'], ['Pre-conditions', 'The caseworker is logged into the system.
An application has been submitted by a beneficiary.

'], ['Success Guarantee (Post-Conditions)', 'The application is either approved or rejected.
'], ['Main Success Scenario', 'The caseworker logs into the system.
The caseworker navigates to the list of pending applications.
The caseworker selects an application to process.
The system displays the application details.
The caseworker reviews the application for completeness and accuracy.
If the application is complete and accurate, the caseworker approves it.
If the application is incomplete or inaccurate, the caseworker rejects it, specifying the reason for rejection.
The system updates the application status as approved or rejected.
If approved, the system proceeds to benefit allocation.
If rejected, the system notifies the beneficiary of the rejection.
'], ['Extensions/Alternatives', 'If the caseworker encounters technical issues or requires assistance, they can seek help from the administrator or technical support.']]

[['Use Case Section', 'Comment'], ['Use Case Name', 'Allocate Benefit'], ['Scope', 'Welfare Empowerment System'], ['Level', 'User-goal'], ['Primary Actor', 'Caseworker'], ['Stockholders & Interest', 'Caseworker: Aims to accurately allocate benefits to eligible beneficiaries.
Beneficiaries: Expect timely and accurate benefit allocation.
'], ['Pre-conditions', 'The caseworker is logged into the system.
An application has been approved.
'], ['Success Guarantee (Post-Conditions)', 'The benefit is allocated to the beneficiary according to the program rules.'], ['Main Success Scenario', "The caseworker logs into the system.
The caseworker navigates to the list of approved applications.
The caseworker selects an approved application to allocate benefits.
The system displays the details of the approved application.
The caseworker reviews the program rules and calculates the benefit amount.
The caseworker allocates the benefit to the beneficiary, specifying the form of assistance (e.g., financial aid, food vouchers).
The system updates the beneficiary's record to reflect the benefit allocation.
The caseworker notifies the beneficiary of the benefit allocation.
"], ['Extensions/Alternatives', 'If the caseworker encounters technical issues or has questions about benefit allocation, they can seek help from the administrator or technical support. ']]

[['Use Case Section', 'Comment'], ['Use Case Name', 'Manage a case'], ['Scope', 'Welfare Empowerment System'], ['Level', 'User-goal'], ['Primary Actor', 'CaseWorker'], ['Stockholders & Interest', 'Caseworker: Aims to efficiently manage beneficiary cases, ensuring they receive the necessary support.
Beneficiaries: Expect timely and appropriate assistance and support.
'], ['Pre-conditions', "The caseworker is logged into the system.
A beneficiary's case is open.
"], ['Success Guarantee (Post-Conditions)', "The beneficiary's case is effectively managed, including interviews, case notes, and updates."], ['Main Success Scenario', "The caseworker logs into the system.
The caseworker navigates to their list of open beneficiary cases.
The caseworker selects a beneficiary's case to manage.
The system displays the beneficiary's case details.
The caseworker conducts interviews or assessments as needed.
The caseworker records case notes, updates beneficiary information, and manages any required actions.
The caseworker can schedule follow-up appointments or actions.
The system updates the beneficiary's case record with the caseworker's actions.
"], ['Extensions/Alternatives', 'If the caseworker encounters technical issues or has questions about case management, they can seek help from the administrator or technical support.']]

[['Use Case Section', 'Comment'], ['Use Case Name', 'Submit Application'], ['Scope', 'Welfare Empowerment System'], ['Level', 'User-goal'], ['Primary Actor', 'Beneficiary'], ['Stockholders & Interest', 'Beneficiary:
Submit an online application for welfare assistance and receive a timely confirmation on successful submission.

Process the submitted application by registering the beneficiary, validating, and verifying the application.

Approves the application.
'], ['Pre-conditions', 'The beneficiary has logged in into the system. He also can track the status of the application and view details of the submitted application.'], ['Main Success Scenario', "The beneficiary accesses the public portal or logs into their account.
The system presents a list of available welfare programs.
The beneficiary selects a program and starts the application process.
The system guides the beneficiary to provide personal information, contact details, family composition, and demographic data.
The beneficiary submits the application with supporting documents.
The system presents a form to the beneficiary, requesting the following information:
Account holder's name
Bank name
Account number
Routing number (if applicable)
Account type (e.g., savings or checking)
Address associated with the bank account.
The beneficiary enters the required bank account details and ensures accuracy.
The system validates the information provided, checking for correct formats and completeness.
If any validation errors occur (e.g., incorrect account number format), the system informs the donor and prompts them to correct the errors.
The system validates the application for completeness and correctness.
If errors are found, the system notifies the beneficiary for corrections.
The application is successfully submitted and validated.
The system generates an application reference number.
The beneficiary receives a confirmation message with the reference number.
"], ['Extensions/Alternatives', '1a. Access Denied.
User re-enters his e-mail and password.
a. System grants access 
b. System repeats 1a thrice.
No-more attempts for some time.
Systems sends a code for confirmation.
1b. User not registered. 
User first register on the system
Provide his name, CNIC, address, contact number.
Successfully registered.
Access portal by providing credentials given during registration process in the last two steps.

2a. If there is no welfare program available, the system notifies the user about unavailability.
User selects an option that states “notify me”. The system then sends a notification whenever any program is available.
7a. The system may specify the invalid fields and areas and request the user for resubmission.
On repeating the same mistake, the system repeats 7a. 
']]

System provides its own account details.

[['Use Case Section', 'Comment'], ['Use Case Name', 'Approve Beneficiary Application
Approve Benefactors’ Programs Application'], ['Scope', 'Welfare Empowerment System'], ['Level', 'User-goal'], ['Primary Actor', 'System Administrator'], ['Stockholders & Interest', 'Administrator:
 Efficiently approve beneficiary programs to ensure timely assistance.

Caseworkers: 
Receive program approvals to assist beneficiaries accordingly.

Beneficiaries:
 Interested in the timely approval of programs to access benefits.
'], ['Pre-conditions', 'The administrator is logged into the system.
Beneficiary program applications are in a pending approval state.

'], ['Success Guarantee (Post-Conditions)', 'Beneficiary program application are either approved or denied.
'], ['Main Success Scenario', 'The administrator logs into the system.
The administrator navigates to the "Pending Application Approvals" section.
The system displays a list of pending beneficiary applications.
The administrator selects an application for review.
The administrator reviews the application details, including eligibility criteria and documentation.
The administrator approves or denies the program based on the review.
If approved, the system updates the program status as "Approved."
If denied, the system updates the program status as "Denied."
The administrator may provide comments or reasons for the decision.
The system sends notifications to caseworkers and beneficiaries and benefactors regarding the program's status.
The administrator repeats the process from step 4 to 10 for other pending programs as needed.
'], ['Extensions/Alternatives', '3a. No programs for review.
System displays “nothing to review.”

5a. Incomplete documents.
Administrator may forward a query to the caseworker.
5b. Suspicious information
May forward details to respective authorities.
Police Department.
']]

[['Use Case Section', 'Comment'], ['Use Case Name', 'Analyze Feedback'], ['Scope', 'Welfare Empowerment System'], ['Level', 'User-goal'], ['Primary Actor', 'System Administrator'], ['Stockholders & Interest', 'System Administrator: 
Interested in analyzing feedback from users to identify system issues and areas for improvement.

Benefactors/Beneficiaries:
want to see their concerns answered, and improvement made to the system. 

'], ['Pre-conditions', 'The administrator is logged into the system.
Users or benefactors have submitted applications.
'], ['Success Guarantee (Post-Conditions)', 'Feedback is analyzed, categorized, and prioritized for potential system enhancements.'], ['Main Success Scenario', 'The administrator logs into the system.
The administrator navigates to the "Feedback Analysis" section.
The system displays a list of feedback submissions, including the date, source (user type), and the feedback content.
The administrator reviews the feedback submissions, categorizing them based on the nature of the feedback.
The administrator prioritizes feedback based on its severity and impact on system performance.
The administrator may communicate with users to gather additional details or clarification regarding their feedback if necessary.
The system tracks the status of each feedback submission (e.g., open, in progress, resolved).
Once feedback is addressed or implemented, the administrator can update the status accordingly.
The administrator ensures that feedback is documented for future reference and monitoring.'], ['Extensions/Alternatives', '4a. The feedback is difficult to comprehend for reasons such as: Language and semantics. 
Administrator drops the feedback.
9a. Feedback not documented/saved.
 System asks a pop question before exiting the system.
System saves the feedback in a temporary buffer.
']]

If applicable, the user can attach relevant documents or evidence to support their feedback.
The user submits the feedback.
The system acknowledges the receipt of the feedback, providing a reference number or confirmation message.
Beneficiaries and benefactors can track the status of their feedback submissions within the system.
System forwards the feedback to the system administrator.
System updates the feedback status. 
Beneficiaries and benefactors receive updates on the status and resolution of their feedback through notifications within the system or email.
'], ['Extensions/Alternatives', '4a. The system should handle sensitive information securely and in compliance with privacy regulations.']]
